Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Determining Interaction Parameters of Roots in Soil
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Philip Benfey (Duke University)

CoPI: Daniel Goldman (Georgia Institute of Technology)

The goal of this EAGER project is to begin to address the question "How do plant roots behave in soil?" Due to the opaque nature of soil, most previous studies have involved digging up roots, observing them in transparent materials, or observing them as they grow against a transparent interface. This project is an early stage effort that has the potential to transform the way root/soil interaction studies are performed. Expertise in the physics of granular matter will be combined with expertise in root biology to explore this area. The experimental plan involves growing rice in cylindrical containers and systematically varying soil parameters. Root response will be imaged with X-ray computed tomography with 3-D root structure reconstructed and analyzed using software previously developed by the PIs.

The project is interdisciplinary (physics and biology) and applies new expertise (physics of granular matter) and new technology (high-resolution X-ray detection). The work also has important practical applications: poor soil fertility and environmental stress suppress crop yields in many parts of the world, and many models predict abiotic stress will increase in coming decades. Thus, enhanced knowledge of root responses to soil composition and soil moisture could be highly beneficial to agriculture, particularly in developing countries. X-ray CT scans of roots and software necessary for analysis will be made available on repository websites at the Georgia Institute of Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this EAGER project is to begin to address the question “How do plant roots behave in soil?”. All currently available methods for phenotyping root systems involve tradeoffs.  A key issue is the opacity and complexity of soil.  Many studies have involved digging up field-grown roots or observing them as they run into an interface such as a rhizotron.  These methods limit the ability to capture the 3-D arrangement of RSA (Root System Architecture) within the soil.  As a result, there exists no comprehensive analysis of root behavior under different soil conditions.  The techniques developed by this project and the results of this study should provide insight into RSA establishment in real soils.  The experimental plan involved performing a comprehensive analysis of root behavior in different soil conditions using a diverse range of rice cultivars. X-ray computed tomography was used to capture root responses in rice grown in cylindrical containers. This research had two main objectives: 1) Development of the X-ray based system for imaging of the rice roots in granular soil, and, 2) Determination of the effect of soil properties on the RSA of different rice cultivars. A key outcome is the development of a low-cost X-ray imaging system for visualization and analysis of 3D architectures on a millimeter and sub-millimeter scale in young plants, which is applicable to study non-plant underground architecture. Our x-ray visualization techniques developed under this funding will be improved and streamlined so that researchers outside our project (and in other fields) can utilize these techniques. We intend to provide equipment, share methodology and expertise with our colleagues to allow tests of hypotheses.  The results revealed changes in RSA in response to granular substrates and has identified QTLs that could lead to a better understanding of root responses to soil compaction. Three postdocs, a MS student, an undergraduate and a high school student were trained on this interdisciplinary project To date the results have primarily been disseminated in seminars given in Denmark, Germany, Japan, China, Italy and the US. A manuscript describing the results of the study was published in Plant Physiology.
